38701339.review:
Пожалуй, одна из лучших игр жанра Rougelike в которые я играл. Куча рас, классов и крутых способностей дают реально огромные возможности для построения своего билда и при этом все достаточно сбалансировано, однако помереть тут можно в легкую, если быть беспечным (новички, пожалуйста, не оживляйте этого робота на кладбище големов, не повторяйте моих ошибок, я это сделал перед концовкой своего очень удачного прохождения и улетел на попной тяге в стратосферу). Реиграбельность высока, особенно с учетом особенностей классов и рас, которые могут начинать игру в совершенно разных локациях и с разным к ним отношением. А если главная сюжетная кампания надоела, то есть еще отдельный мир в dlc, а также режим арены и бесконечного подземелья.

Также у мира достаточно интересный лор с кучей текста, не сказать, что для такого жанра это важно, но это реально сделало мир живым. И еще музыка, саундтрек хорош, за это спасибо.

Единственный минус - это сам мир, который при каждой игре один и тот же, меняется лишь расположение нескольких локаций.

Хочу пожелать долгого процветания игре, надеюсь разработчик продолжит дополнять игру контентом, она этого достойна.

38676676.review:
It's roguelike, it's fun, and it's hackable.

ToME is a modern-ish, roguelike, turn-based rpg with incredible modding support. It features procedurally generated content laid on top of decent premade lore. Decent, nothing too amazing, but not too shabby either. In fact, I enjoy following some of the dungeon lore, and hasn't come to find lore notes that are particularly annoying or inconsistently written. Gameplay is fun, but let's talk about it in a series of pros and cons:

Pros
- Relatively balanced race / classes with different play styles
- Enemies don't respawn, meaning you *probably* don't need to grind
- Decent amount of side quest and extra dungeon
- Mode with extra lives for those who suck at roguelike, like me
- Hackable, with a crap ton of addons already out there

Cons
- It's pretty barebones, and might be hard to get into. You may need to get past tier-1 dungeons several times and play with different classes to fully grasp what you're really doing in this game.
- Steep difficulty increase with little to no warning in some areas

It's well-made, and it's worth the price. When in doubt, go get the free version, which is the full game minus several cosmetic feature and the convenience of Steam Workshop support.

38361436.review:
Tales of Maj'Eyal (ToME) is an Open Source rogue-like with two alternate campaign storylines and lots of classes and races to choose from. You start the game with a very limited selection of races and classes, and then must unlock the others as you play. 

That prelude said, the game is relatively linear in that you pick a race and class and start at Level 1. You move through tiered dungeons that never change. The content within them is relatively random except for the dungeon bosses, however the dungeons themselves and the order in which you move through them tends to always stay the same no matter how many times you have been through them or which character you play. The only thing that really does change is the race/class and the points you spend in them as you level up. This is constrained by the fact that certain class/race builds tend to always be more successful than others. In addition, one race in particular - Shalore - is very overpowered making some of the classes you play as Shalore basically an automatic game winner.

The main developer Dark God is very responsive to the community and he works as a volunteer, as is customary in most Open Source projects. You can donate to the game if you like it to help support his efforts. The game is user friendly for Linux and MAC as well.

The games cons are its inflexiblity and redundant nature. The pros are its fantastic lead developer and the community.

37980126.review:
This game is complex, but unlike most games, entirely in ways that make sense.  Every death felt deserved and every reward hard earned.  The stat and resist systems make perfect sense, and every choice you make in building your character feels impactful.  The sheer variety in builds is staggering.

Unlike most roguelikes, TOME has a huge story that requires multiple playthroughs as multiple classes making multiple choices to fully appreciate the scope of the story.

The game is open-source and the base content can be downloaded for free at their website.  I strongly recommend trying it if you like roguelikes or complex RPG mechanics, doubly so if you enjoy post-apocalyptic fantasy settings.

37907752.review:
Very nice roguelike that is constantly tweaked and upgraded.
If you're into roguelike, you know already what you're going into.
If not, there are things you might want to know:
The game is very long, tries to be balanced and has permadeath and boss fights.
It means that you have literally no chance to see the end as is.
Thus, to fully appreciate the game, I suggest the following:
1) Set short goals; experiment with classes and races, unlock things and try many playstyles.
2) Try a few playthrough with infinite lives enabled.
3) Do not hesitate to read guides and walkthrough online.
In short, do not try to be badass or play the game "as it means to be played" if you find other ways are more enjoyable. The options are there, use them!

37849381.review:
This is the sort of game that has the potential to become an obsession if it really ticks your boxes.  ToME is my first rogue-like, and what attracted me to it was the fact that it looks like the love child of a SRPG and an ARPG.  If that sounds good to you, let me tell you that it really delivers on that promise.  This is essentially a single character game of Final Fantasy Tactics staged across a series of Diablo dungeons.  I love it.

I have hundreds of hours logged so far, and even though I've won a few times, I still feel like I have lots to do if only because of the sheer number of classes and achievements, not to mention that I've yet to move beyond the Normal difficulty level or try any of the numerous community developed add-ons.  Even so, I'm well aware of just how flexible the add-ons make the game.  If you like unlocking everything yourself as I do, there's a fair number of unlocks to chase, but if you want all the classes immediately, you can get the add-on that does that.  Play how you want to!

Speaking on which, if you are turned off by by the idea of a rogue-like but otherwise think this looks interesting, it's worth knowing that the default mode is the more forgiving "Adventure" mode, which is more akin to the limited continues of an old-school NES game.  The game remains hard, but with some practice, a few extra lifes prove to be a pretty good cushion.  There's even an "Exploration" mode with unlimited lives if you'd really rather be sure you can finish.

The game still gets updates as well, and that looks likely to continue for the foreseeable future.  There are two additional DLCs in the works at the moment, as well as occasional updates to the core game for balancing or even the occasional new class.  Good stuff.

37824749.review:
Best roguelike in recent years with modern quality-of-life improvements that many roguelikes sadly neglect (i.e rebindable hotkeys, customisable UI or even just having sprites at all!)

There are tons of classes with different skills that allows different playstyle though it does go with my one complaint - too many of these classes rely on just a differently named resource bar (i.e. renamed mana) though some do have unique ways of generation/replenishment.

Damage of certain magic/ranged enemies can also be reduced as they can 1 or 2-shot you and newbies are advised to avoid "vaults". This does somewhat restrict builds to require some sort of "ohshit" button or certain damage migitation skills. Melee classes are naturally harder to play/weaker because of this. Randomness on drops (but what's a roguelike without this?) and escort quests can also be annoying but that can be worked around because..

Everything can be modded out or in if you dislike something about the game. You can edit the entire game and engine itself if you know LUA and I have to recommend this game just for that alone. Or just download something from the workshop.

The full game is also provided free by the author on his website (minus the DLCs) so there's really no risk to trying it out. Buying it here (or gog or his own website) is just a way to say you support him like donation/shareware games of old.

37320906.review:
Imagine creating a character, going through quests and being really happy with his awesome super lucky dropped sword and the perfect quest rewards to fit your play style. He dies miserably to the first mishap.

Now imagine the opposite, a pretty meh character you don't care for never getting the right stuff you want. He somehow survives twice as long as previous character.

Even though they both die, you probably managed to unlock a new class, or race or skill tree on top of all the already existing choices, allowing you to try for a fresh start with a character that can play completely different than the previous one, which combined with random elements make it surprisingly replayable.

Nightmare difficulty is my recommended difficulty, it helps speed the starter levels up which is great when you are constantly remaking characters on permadeath (which I recommend over the lives system personally), as well as adding more rare encounters.

Its worth the 7$, otherwise you can get the base game for free as well from the game's website. I played it for years, and purchased the game on steam later to support the development. Plays well on both linux and windows.

37121650.review:
I've been playing Tales of Maj'Eyal (aka TOME 4) on and off for almost 6 years now. TOME is the definition of a modern classic Roguelike. It eschews standards to encourage more time playing and less time managing.

There is one major exception: TOME has a crazy number of skill options for every character. I have spent way too much time considering which skill to take and then regretting my decisions later. Those regrets do diminish over time as I get better at choosing.

I could write a long review. So much of TOME is deep and takes quite a while to understand. It's very easy to get into, though, and I can easily recommend TOME to anyone. 36958479.review:
Tales of Maj'Eyal is the game that finally got me addicted to roguelikes. 

There a several reasons for that. The acessible graphics and interface helped, but what truly sets ToME apart is how it blends the roguelike formula with more traditional RPG elements AND an amazing tactical turn-based combat.

First, it's a roguelike, but you unlock new classses and races as you play, so there's a sense a progression things even if you die. And if you don't enjoy losing your character you can disable permadeth - or give youself some extra lives.

The world is fixed, but races/classes have different starting points and many quests have multiple solutions, so there's always something new to see or try in each playthrough. In one your Psionic Dwarf might become a mage hunter that vows to never use magic items, in the other your Elven Necromancer might join an evil warlock and raid the mage hunters.

Finally, the classes, races and items are all designed to offer you plenty of choices in combat. ToME will throw crazy challenges at you, but it also offers crazy powers - travel back in time, turn into a demon, redirect damage, teleport, raise walls, summon tsunamis, become a lich, etc. It's never about level or DPS - what's important is using your skills wisely.   

So if you always wanted to try a roguelike but ADOM, NetHack and other classics never got you hooked, try ToME. :)

36543418.review:
Tales of Maj'Eyal: Age of Ascendancy, ou mais conhecido como Tome 4.
Tome 4 é um roguelike (está bem, eu confesso que sou apaixonado por este estilo de jogo) código aberto, totalmente desenvolvido em lua, extremamente divertido e old school. A melhor forma de descrever o tome 4 seria como um roguelike super tunado, isso porque além das características comuns aos jogo estilo rogue como morte permanente e calabouços gerados a cada partida, ele ainda possui melhorias como gráficos caprichados ainda que sejam apenas tiles, possui áudio dos monstros e espadas em combates, alem de possuir um tema musical muito gostoso de se ouvir enquanto é jogado. 
Mas as melhorias que realmente me impressionaram no tome 4 é o fato do jogo ser mundo aberto, diferente de outros roguelikes como stone soup, onde você explora apenas uma masmorra. Outro ponto interessante é o game também possuir quests e trama interligando todos os acontecimentos.
Outra inovação do tome 4 é o jogo possuir recursos online. Deixa eu explicar. Você infelizmente não vai poder jogar cooperativamente com outros players, nem desafia-los, mas poderá se comunicar com outros players em tempo real, seja para pedir dicas ou comemorar quando matar um monstro poderoso. O modo online também comunica a todos os jogadores de forma automática quando um determinado player completa uma quest, passa de level ou encontra algum segredo. E o melhor, ele grava todas as informações do seu jogo no site do tome 4, lá você pode comparar seu personagem com o de outros amigos e até estimular uma disputa para ver quem consegue evoluir e ir o mais longe possível.
O jogo não é tão difícil como seu irmão stone soup. Mas está longe de ser uma baba, os jogadores casuais vão sofrer um pouco no inicio, mas vão se apaixonar quando entender o funcionamento. Para finalizar gostaria de dar algumas dicas ao jogadores iniciantes:
Algumas classes são desbloqueadas após jogatinas no game, então fique esperto para explorar o máximo que conseguir, isso te garantirá mais opções de escolha de classes em futuros games.
Abuse das suas skills, elas são importantes para te manter vivo em muitas batalhas.
Evite carregar tudo que encontrar nos calabouços, leve apenas o que encontrar de valor, isso evita você ficar pesado e receber penalidades em combates.
Aperte J no teclado para abrir as quests disponíveis, siga a ordem delas para evitar entrar em uma área com monstros muito fortes para seu level.
Venda sempre seu loot na cidade para conseguir mais dinheiro para equipamentos.
Evite lutar com vários monstros de uma só vez, busque no cenario locais onde possa enfrentar um por um.
Recomendo o jogo para todos aqueles que adoram jogos de exploração no estilo rogue. Alem de tudo o jogo é gratuito fora da steam. Terminei comprando na steam para ajudar mesmo, mas tenho muitas horas de tome4 desde a epoca de sua primeira versão.

http://nerdone.blogspot.com.br/2012/04/tales-of-majeyal-age-of-ascendancy-tome.html

最经典，也是最容易入门的的roguelike之一。
永久死亡，随机关卡，回合制是roguelike最明显的特征，在埋藏在更深的则是由于系统的复杂度带来@的几乎无限的自由。这种自由的感觉是任何所谓3A（包括辐射系列，老滚系列，GTA系列等）都无法带来的。
另外roguelike中辅助玩家的自动探索、自动拾取功能也是足够优秀的发明。

而ToME4则是在roguelike游戏中极为偏重战斗&画面&剧情的RPG，种类繁多的职业&装备，各种奇葩build。

引用开发者DarkGod的话：“roguelike的伟大之处在于，你经常要思考“下一回合我就要死了，我现在必须做什么”。之后你可以停下想五分钟，你的下一步是什么。你可能会死，但你也可能会找到一个自己没记得的奇怪能力、或是一种聪明的方式来使用某种物品之类的。你成功拯救了自己的生命，然后想道：“我好强！”。”

Tales of Maj'Eyal u ToME, é um jogo para quem gosta de desafios.

35979406.review:
This game is available for free on the developer's website.  The Steam version allows you to unlock a few more classes (and helps support the dev).


This is one of the best true roguelikes.  It's hard, it's complicated, and you will die.  It's also a lot of fun.  Character builds are complex, the fights are challenging and intense, and there's a sense of progression by unlocking classes and game modes.


The downsides (or, why I mentioned the free version at the top) are a dated engine, horrible UI, and repetitive gameplay.  Still, the game is worth the price and worth the time.  Try the free version and I'm sure you'll pick it up here.

34752903.review:
[i]Never played rouge but I do like the likes.[/i] The hard to pronounce Tales of Maj'Eyal is an old school rougelike and has it's roots in the origins of the genre. Rouge begat Moria which begat angband which begat tales of middle earth which begat early ToME, in a development path that goes all the way back to the early eighties. The assets of the game are well designed and the game plays smoothly and smartly. The game features numerous races and classes which are original and fun to play as, and makes the prospect of death much less of an annoyance. This is a proper old school rouglike in every sense of the term

[h1] Good [/h1]
-has this cool otherworld kind of appeal
-well constructed world, good writing 
-great character classes, interesting and powerful skills
-tough but fair
-usefull interface with autocasting and other handy options

If you've been losing your sleep with your friend playing pen-and-paper RPGs, this game is for you. If you never played a roguelike game, this game is afaik the best available. If you don't know what a roguelike game is, you MAY not like it at all: forget fancy graphics and immerse yourself into a story-rich adventure that is always fresh to replay.

My suggestion for anyone that has a decent experience in roguelike games is to play it from the beginning at maximum difficulty: one life only AND nightmare settings. Only this way you will fear that any click could be the last, and have a total immersive experience.

34632410.review:
Tales of Maj'Eyal es, con toda seguridad, uno de los mejores 'roguelike' que se han hecho hasta la fecha. Da igual que lleves veinte años jugando a Rogue, Moria y Nethack; o que por el contrario no hayas tocado el género en tu vida. Lo absolutamente maravilloso de ToME es que es capaz de adaptarse a la experiencia y estilo de juego de cada jugador. Que quieres ir tranquilo: modo exploración. Que quieres una experiencia 'pura': roguelike-nightmare. Y lo de las distintas clases y razas es un disparate. Cada clase es un mundo y hace que la experiencia global sea distinta. 

Tras 40 horas tengo la impresión de haber rascado muy poco en la superficie del juego. Y eso me encanta. Me encanta porque cada partida sabes más del trasfondo, del mundo y, sobre todo, de las mecánicas internas del juego. Recomendadísimo para cualquiera que quiera empezar con los 'roguelike' o afianzarlos como uno de sus géneros preferidos.

34496085.review:
What to say.... It was my second Roguelike game that I played seriously and totally fell for it.
I'll jott down some of the main reasons:
[list]
[*] Incredible different play styles depending on the class/builds, I had never seen something remotely approaching before
[*] Despite this a remarkable overall balance
[*] Excellent system of meta-progression
[*] Deep lore, lots of love here from the developper
[*] Great tactical combat system, not too hard, not too easy
[*] Huge and helpful community
[*] Always being updated with new contents and fixes
[*] TE4.org that keeps forever the memory of the fallen heroes 
[*] Not only for hardcore Roguelike fans, difficulties settings for everyone
[/list]

As nothing is perfect I'll suggest a few improvements, which I am not the first to make:
[list]
[*] Part of the second half of the game is kinda repetitive and plain grinding, namely [spoiler] the Orc Fortresses [/spoiler], there is room for improvement here. The character has almost reached its peak performance at this stage, the focus should be on story rather than mob genocide.
[*] Unlocked achivements should automatically unlock the same achivements in lower difficulties whenever applicable
[*] Limited vault size (ok this is personal. I'd love to stash more for my future guys !!)
[/list]

To conclude, if you are a RPG enthusiast and can tolerate retro graphics you MUST buy this game.
One of my best gaming experinces since I was a teen !

34485174.review:
ToME gehört zu meinen absoluten Lieblings-Roguelikes. Aber es ein Roguelike zu nennen, trifft es eigentlich nicht wirklich. 

Es hat eine große Kampagne, für die ich über 60 Stunden gebraucht habe. Man hat unzählige Texte zum lesen, also jede menge Lore über die Welt, die Rassen, die Artefakte..usw. die tlw. wirklich gut und spannend geschrieben sind (alles Englisch) - und ich habe noch lange nicht alles erforscht und gesehen. Obwohl ich mir Mühe gegeben hatte, jeden Winkel zu erforschen, habe ich gerade mal 1%(!), ja, -ein- Prozent der Errungenschaften.

Man wählt aus vielen, auch recht ungewöhnlichen Rassen und Klassen, Fähigkeiten, Zaubern, Infusions, Gegenständen, Artefakten und was-weiß-ich noch alles. Zu Beginn, also beim ersten Spielen, ist man jedoch auf sehr wenige (Rassen, Klassen) begrenzt, man schaltet durch Spielen immer mehr frei.

Beim Spielen sind die Levelaufstiege und auch der Loot, also neue Ausrüstung, von Anfang bis zum Ende sehr befriedigend. Man weiß oft nicht, was man nehmen will, weil die Auswahl so gut ist. Und auch weil das System sehr komplex ist - bei weitem nicht alles versteht man auf Anhieb - aber im Laufe der Spielstunden kommt das fast nebenbei. 

Anfangs, die ersten Stunden, dachte ich, daß das Spiel viel zu leicht ist. Ich hätte gerne etwas, wo man nachdenken und taktieren, den Charakter und die Ausrüstung optimieren muss. Aber das kommt! In einer perfekten Lernkurve, bis hin zu einem sehr anspruchsvollen Schwierigkeitsgrad.

Man könnte noch sehr viel schreiben, aber ich möchte nur noch sagen: Ich bereue, daß ich dieses Spiel so lange ungespielt in meiner Bibliothek hatte.

34443640.review:
This is a pretty gem of a game, just not in the litteral sense of the word pretty as it looks like an 8 bit nintendo game from 1991.

Is that a problem?

Not at all. The awesome class mechanics, dungeons and range of items more then makes up for the lack of pleasing visuals and I had a blast playing the game so far.

Allow me to relate two encounter my archer had that hopefully illustrate the brilliant randomness from the game:

1) Carefully exploring a dungeon she was jumped by two vampires who disarmed and offbalanced her. Being helpless she struck her rune of random teleportation and vanished from the vampires eyes!

Only to appear smack in the middle in a huge oval room filled to the brim with HUGE spiders, still disarmed and off balance. She managed to survive by jumping over six ranks of spiders into a corridor and fighting them one by one but it was some frantic combat.

2) Walking in an empty room my archer walked to the far wall where some items where on the floor, avoiding a so called lava floor in the middle. When she picked up an item four walls slid back and four powerfull orcish mages surrounded her utterly. Surrounded by four spellcaster who could toast her easily (she couldnt shoot more then one due to their placing and they had heaps of status affects that would completely render her helpless) she used her rune and vanished!

Only to re-appear in the same room smack in the middle of the lava ground, still surrounded by no doubt snickering orcish mages. RIP archer. May their death be as painfull as yours was.

That brings me to my last remark: Don't play this game to succeed, play this game to have fun exploring and expecting horrible death at every corner. Never get careless for death can hide EVERYWHERE!

(There are however modes to give you more life so worry not if you like your mayhem more casually and forgiving)

34384816.review:
Had this for a while. Looked interesting, but I was put off by the graphics. Stupid really as I know good graphics do not make a good game.
I was moved to take another look when my graphics card blew up and I needed to get my gaming fix from games that will play nice with an outdated onboard graphics chip.
What a gem! And what a fool I was for ignoring this for so long. It is difficult to explain why this is so good, without a lengthy review; but if you enjoy roguelikes, or light RPGs, or turn based tactical combat, then this outstanding hybrid will really deliver.
At first it was struggle to get it set up how I wanted it and to understand how the systems worked.I spent a long time configuring the resolution and the HUD. I read the wiki and trawled the internet for answers to obscure or unexplained game mechanics and suddenly it clicked. My first death felt cruel, I had invested so much into my Lady Brienne character. My grief was shortlived, as I instantly created a new and very different character and set out again. Now I knew some of the lore and could see the multiple ways of playing the game.
This is an excellent game from a single developer, he deserves your support. It has crashed into my top 100; and is heading for the top ten with every hour I unlock it's secrets and survive a little longer. This game will remain on my hard drive for a very long time as there are endless new runs to try out.

34319916.review:
Tales of Maj'Eyal (formly Tales of Middle-Earth, which is based off the Angband branch, which in turn is off Moria...history!) AKA TOME...is a classical roguelike definately worth playing. 

If you've never played a real genuine roguelike before, this game is probably one of the best starting points to get a real feel for the genre since it is very accessible (logical mouse and hot keys controls) and friendly. (you can die and still continue depending on the customizable difficulty)

The classes really do feel very distinct and there are a lot of them. (and many more you'll unlock and more besides) The writing is mostly good and even comical at parts. And of course with all roguelikes, there is the learning of the thing. You level up alongside your characters in how to best progress through the game without dying. Good luck.

34171998.review:
这游戏有毒..首先作为回合制roguelike游戏，它有比较多大胆的设计，比如说有个时空系的技能叫命运螺旋，可以在三条时间线里分别做出行动，然后在里面选择一条作为现在的时间线。

具体说就是，你先在效果限定时间的数回合内正常进行行动，然后跳回到数回合前，再进行行动，再跳回一次，再行动，一共行动三次，根据结果来选择其中比较满意的一次作为现实。

这个例子已经很强大了，还有个装备的例子也很有意思，叫“命运之轮”，是个戒指，应该算是欧皇之戒，因为它的特效是随机重置戒指的属性。

但是重置次数是有限制的，每3级获得一次机会，并且，在没有重置机会同时没到50级的情况下，不能卸下戒指。。这游戏，50级算是后期了，所以前期要是运气不好，随机到对职业没好处的属性就有点难受，这倒没什么，但是重置时的系统提示有点耐人寻味：

“戒指里的头骨似乎扭曲了一瞬间……它刚才笑了么？”

这个戒指实际上是有段故事的，这里不展开讲，建议到游戏里去看(o゜▽゜)o☆

这些设计和一些背景故事让这个游戏不再是机械地重复砍杀，而是引人思索这个机制要如何运用，以及尝试去理解这个世界的人和事物。这样的游戏可说是丰富多彩的。

游戏的技能树相对来说很有宽度，但稍欠深度，种类比较多，同类的比较少，所以讲究各类型技能的配合。

总结起来，这款游戏有着丰富的内容和较高的可玩性，值得一试。

33718576.review:
Ta gra jest niesamowicie dobra! Tu jest tyle różnych ras, klas, lokacji, umiejętności, wrogów, poziomów trudności i questów, że nie jestem w stanie podać nazwy innej takiej gry. Można przez całą grę Bulwarkiem parować ciosy przeciwników i wycinać ich w pień, a na ostatniej bitwie zostać bezlitośnie zgniecionym jak robak!

Można tu odblokować bardzo dużo różności, których nie da się zrobić grając jedną kombinacją. Niektóre rasy zaczynają w lesie, inne w mieście magów, a jeszcze inne w jaskini nekromanty czy wyspie niedostępnej dla innych. Nie chcesz grać kampanii? W porządku, jest tryb Infinite Dungeon, który nigdy się nie kończy! Albo możesz powalczyć na arenie o tytuł Wielkiego Mistrza. Osiągnięć jest tu NAPRAWDĘ SPORO (podzielonych na 9 poziomów). 

Jest również bardzo dużo różnych dodatków w Workshopie, które mogą kompletnie zmienić zasady gry, jak i zwykłe pomoce typu "Własne notatki".  Poza tym można stworzyć swoją własną grę na tym silniku i wgrać ją obok oryginału. Najlepsze jest to, że ta gra jest całkowicie za darmo na stronie te4.org. Jednak za cenę podstawki i 2 dodatków dostajemy jeszcze więcej rzeczy typu nowe klasy, kampanię orków, osiągnięcia, tryb eksploracji, że naprawdę się opłaca się wesprzeć autora.

Naprawdę gorąco polecam kupić i bez żadnych promocji. Nie znam innej gry, która i za darmo oferowałaby taką grywalność. Wciąga jak nie wiem co!

33533975.review:
If you want a relatively easy entry into the world of roguelikes, ToME is definitely the game for you. While you don't need to learn a billion different key combinations in order to do the actions you want, you will most likely be overwhelmed by the massive amounts of activateable skills and items that you earn over the game. The character building options will also most likely overwhelm you. Your characters will be trash for a while until you get the hang of the system.

Having the option to play on modes that aren't quite as punishing as roguelike is always a plus for those getting into roguelikes, but where's the fun in that? I mean, I did just play a single character for some twenty odd hours before dying on the last boss, losing all the progress. I wasn't mad. Honest.

For whatever it's worth, ToME is the first game in closer to half a decade that has caused me to play for seven hours in a row. Seven. Hours.

Get it. Reward the active developers of the game. Or don't. I'm not your dad.

ridiculous number of skills and abilities,   you might think, "damn, this game is old-looking, it can't have good combat, it looks so simple!".

you'd be wrong.  this game is one of the best games i've ever played as far as roguelikes are concerned.

my ONLY qualm is that it's so hard sometimes even on normal roguelike setting  that i get frustrated and quit.  i put almost 200 hours into it and i still havent managed to beat the game on normal roguelike. i refuse to use adventure mode though, having multiple lives feels like cheating to me.   i ALMOST got to the boss on one character but got REKT by some random miniboss rare mob spawn, so sad.

buy this game if you like LOTS OF CLASSES, RACES, SKILLS, epic loot, powerful spells and VERY challenging combat.

so many quality of life features like autoexploring a map to get new characters leveled up quickly.

actually i have one more qualm, the dungeons aren't varied enough for my taste so after your 30th character you kinda get tired of doing the same 5 or 6 starter dungeons every time. 

other than that, 9.5/10   goddamn good game and worth every penny.

33500456.review:
Я уже готов составить свое мнение от игрового процесса.

Tales of Maj'Eyal - это много лет существующий и отлично зарекомендовавший себя "рогалик": умер - давай ещё раз. 
Сразу хочу сказать, что игра бесплатна и доступна на оф сайте для скачивания, но купить на распродаже её вместе со всеми аддонами за какие-то 150р - идеальное вложение средств и превосходная благодарность разработчикам! 

Присутствует и автоматическая генерация подземелий, несмотря на статичную "Карту Мира". Это добавляет некоторую изюминку, согласитесь.
Хотелось бы отметить и тот факт, что если играешь далеко не в первый раз, уже знаешь все локации на карте, представляешь, где искать нужные артефакты с боссов и имеешь представления о местах, которые стоит посещать в первую очередь - это только плюс, так как теперь можно перейти на уровень выше по сложности и попробовать себя там. 

Приятно радует обилие рас, классов и талантов, которые не доступны сразу, а открываются по мере игры. Это лишь подогревает интерес и прямо таки заставляет перепройти игру снова, взглянув на неё под другим углом.

Так же плюс - в игре присутствует Мастерская, в которой имеется множество интересных улучшений, доработок, настроек. 
Онлайн статистика игры на сайте не дает заскучать и позволяет просмотреть как свои, так и чужие результаты похождений по миру Maj'Eyal
Ну и, конечно же, английския язык. Ввиду того, что это всё же RPG - местами присутствует тонна текста лора, немало специфическим параметров и характеристик, что, порой, заставляет посидеть со словарем в стремлении догнать суть происходящего. И это так же положительный момент, ведь нет ничего лучше саморазвития и стремления к совершенствованию. Хейтеров же хочу успокоить - на форуме  Zone of Games имеется ветка перевода игры, но оготовности пока судить рано. Да и в сетях есть добрые русскоязычные сообщества, стремящиеся помочь новичкам.

33492724.review:
This is one of the titles I give as an example whenever I tell people there is a negative correlation between price and playtime of titles in my library. As an overwhelming amount of other reviewers have stated, the depth if this piece is incredible, in my opinion it is the de-facto status quo when it comes to replayability. It swiftly hits that Goldilocks zone between randomization and hand-crafting of the world that makes a roguelike fun to play, and not a random unpredictable mess. Because the Unique and Elite mobs have randomized skill sets, there will be the occasional OMGWTFBBQ moment when a character gets oneshotted by some overpowered RNG fluke, but usually one will know the exact decision that led to a characters death, and mostly it was not retreating when all teleports were on cooldown.

TL;DR; buy,

33256145.review:
I will now review as much of the game as I have experienced so far:

I start the game, the menu is well designed and easy to navigate and pleasant.  The music is good to boot!

Then I press the "New Game" button and prepare myself to create my very first character.  Sitting at the edge of my seat my imagination goes wild with the vast array of possibilities. 
Then the best part, the screen goes black and fidgets and the game pops up with a "an error has occured" page and asks if I would like to report it.  Being of sound mind and body, I decide to report it.  The game then restarts and I am free to roam the menus free from errors once again.

In closing I will say that this game is a wonderful addition to the burgeoning Menu Simulator genre.  A genre that I truly hope continues to grow as game developers show love and attention in creating games that function properly.

Note: I will expand this review if and when I get the game to run as advertised.  Furthermore,  I will change this to review to recommend the game if one of two things happens.
1. If the game developer changes the genre to "Fantasy Menu Simulator" and advertises it as such. OR
2. If a patch comes out, making it so that as a consumer I do not need to immediately fix the "finished" product I have purchased and the game is indeed as fun as it looks.

As it sits, based on my experience I cannot recommend this game even if it were free.  Due to the fact that from my current expercience and perspective I would be telling people to install a game that cannot make it past the menu.

Edit: Thanks to a very helpful fan of the game I have found out that the game is indeed free and you may find it at https://te4.org

However, this does not change my opinion.  I cannot recommend spending time trying to get a game to run that has been out since 2012, and has been actively updated and patched since that time (again huge props to the dev for that) but still is difficult to get running on a mid-level gaming PC.  I understand some long standing fans will disagree with me, and that is fine, this is a free country after all.

Final Edit: Clearly the fans of this game are dedicated.  So, if this game can inspire the kind of loyalty I witnessed since writing one long-winded negative review than it must be a good game, because the mob is never wrong. Thank you. Specifically to those who commented on my review for giving me a good chuckle, that has made my time with this game worth while.

33163055.review:
ToME is a great true, modern roguelike, and I highly recommend it - above Dungeons of Dredmor and Sword of the Stars: The Pit (the other true roguelikes I own on Steam). The graphics and UI are decent, there's a ton of lore, quests, races & classes, lots of unlockable stuff (including classes), sound+music, etc.

The gameplay is challenging, but there are multiple difficulty levels. ToME uses Diablo-style skill trees and an MMO-style  (i.e. cooldown and resource limited) character abilities system.

ToME also supports user-created addons via either Steam Workshop or the game's web site (te4.org), which is great for fixing annoyances and/or adding conveniences as desired.

The game is actively maintained, with regular releases that add new content and features, and rebalance various aspects of the game.

If you like roguelikes and/or ToME looks interesting to you, I strongly suggest trying the demo from their website.

33054963.review:
10/10 - Best Roguelike I've ever played.

1. DEPTH - This game is the holy grail of roguelikes, a hidden diamond in the rough -- if you like the roguelike genre at all and don't have this game, buy it immediately. The depth is insane and best of all it manages to break out of the "fantasy" cliché of classes while still maintaining core principles of a turn based roguelike. Some of the concepts are so foreign that you won't initially understand the mechanics and you're like "what the actual #$%& does this do", but once you learn the mechanics they add a whole new layer of fun to the game that's all but lost in games today.

2. MECHANICS - It's like nothing you've ever seen. Each class and race is eerily unique in several ways and is filled with all kinds of new and interesting ideas. “Wait, I can melee with mind abilities?”

3. ITEMIZATION - Lots of gear, lots of stats, lots of resist types, lots of damage types, lots of status effects, lots of "hmmm I wonder if this piece is better" or "I really should put these points into health, but I can't say no to more damage and if I kill them fast, they can’t hurt me! Right?"  Changing gear usually requires a compromise of offense, defense and knowledge of what your character can handle.

4. CHALLENGE - Took me ~85 gameplay hours to beat the game on Normal, I probably lost 20-30 characters before successfully winning. It's possible that I'm just really bad, but I like to think the game is just really challenging. Also, the beginning of the game is not easy, it's quite difficult; I remember thinking "Wow I just died 3 times in the first starting zone."

5. SKILLS - A huge variety of skills, trees, opportunities and playstyles. This makes for fun and inventive combos, skill synergy and interesting deaths. "Hellll yeah I got a skill that lets me move through walls, oh #$%! I just suffocated in the wall."

6. MONSTERS - A massive monster variety, each time you play you'll start to notice the different monster types, their skills, strengths and weaknesses. On higher difficulties, it's extremely important to know what you're going up against to get that next level advantage. “OHHHH #$%* another necromancer.”

7. ACTIVE DEV & COMMUNITY - Active development on the game, balance patches, new classes, races, and content (DLC). The community is great, can be very helpful and from my experience non-toxic (I guess we're not call of duty scrubs). As a bonus, every now and then you'll see messages from the DarkGod (DEV) who bestows you with some random buff for "absolutely no reason."

8. DEATH - You will die a lot. You will rage. You will learn from your mistakes. You will make the same mistakes again, die, and rage more. You will lose multiple lives to the same monster because you’re too stubborn to choose the “safe” option when talking to the ghost lady after you die. You will switch to another class because the one you were playing before felt 'weak' and this other class has GOT to be better, but then later go back to the first class because you now understand that it's really strong and you were just bad. You will die to the first boss in the first zone ON NORMAL and come to some inevitable realizations about how the game is meant to be played. You’ll say to yourself -- "WELP that guy just 1 shot me for 1565 blight damage, when I only had 923 heath good to know I stood a chance; probably should have more than 11% blight resist."

9. JUST BUY THE GAME - If you've read up to here you could have already lost 2 characters in the addicting, adrenaline fueled, unforgiving journey to save Maj’Eyal.

32403276.review:
Ce jeu est absolument incroyable ! J'y ai déjà joué 70h et j'ai l'impression de n'avoir fait que l'effleurer.

+ Je n'ai pas encore débloqué toutes les classes et les races jouables mais je suis déjà bluffé, chacune à son style de jeu propre. Chaque classe a au moins une ou deux catégories de compétence qu'on ne trouvera pas ailleurs. En dehors de la santé, très peu de classes ont des ressources en commun, certaines utilisent le mana, certaines l'endurance, d'autres l'équilibrium, d'autres encore un mélange de plusieurs, etc. ce qui pourrait paraître un gadget si chacune n'avait pas sa manière de fonctionner. Par exemple pour regagner l'endurance, il suffit d'attendre sans l'utiliser par contre pour l'équilibrium, il démarre à 0 et plus il est élevé plus les compétences lancées avec ont de chance d'échouer. Les classes sont donc bien différentes les unes et autres et souvent elles ont même plusieurs manières d'être jouées, ce qui laisse à penser que tout le monde pourra trouver son style. Un avertissement cependant, certaines classes sont (de mon avis personnel) plus ou moins puissantes ce qui permet d'une certaine manière de moduler la difficulté mais ça peut aussi surprendre parfois.

+ Et d'ailleurs, maintenant que j'en parle de la difficulté, sachez qu'elle est au rendez-vous. Dans ToME, il n'y a pas cette sensation des premiers niveaux difficiles et une fois qu'on a monté son perso on roule sur tout le monde. Que nenni, on trouvera toujours un challenge à sa hauteur (en sachant que je n'ai jamais fini le jeu je m'avance peut être un peu mais je ne pense pas). Plus votre perso est complexe et peut gérer de situations problématiques, plus l'éventail de ces situations sera large et simultané.

+ Un autre grand atout de ce jeu, c'est tout ce qu'on peut débloquer. Ça peut aller d'un nouvel élément à utiliser pour les mages à un nouveau mode de jeu en passant par de nouvelles races et classes. C'est toujours un plaisir de débloquer un nouvel élément dans ce jeu et ça se fait souvent au prix de longs efforts et d'expériences répétées de morts approchées.

+ Un aspect de ce jeu que j'aime particulièrement, c'est le lore. Je trouve l'univers de ce jeu réellement intéressant et avec des choix dans l'histoire du monde que je n'ai pas vu souvent, voire jamais. Je ne m'étendrais pas plus sur ce sujet, je vous laisse découvrir...

+ Et je n'ai pas encore abordé la chose la plus incroyable dans ce jeu : vous pouvez y jouer gratuitement avec seulement quelques options en moins (une classe et deux campagnes il me semble) en le téléchargeant sur le site officiel. De quoi vous laisser l'essayer autant que vous voulez avant de soutenir ou pas ce jeu (ce que j'ai fait par ailleurs).

- Ceci dit, je ne suis pas payé par l'éditeur pour vous servir uniquement des compliments béats, il y a aussi des défauts dans ce jeu. Le premier qui me vient en tête, c'est vraiment le niveau des quêtes. Autant je suis fan de l'univers et je dévore tout le lore que je trouve, autant les seuls quelques personnages qui vont vous adresser la parole en dehors de la quête principale sont tout droit sortis d'un mauvais scénar de donjons & dragons. Hormis une ou deux quêtes travaillées il n'y a pas grand chose.

- Un autre point négatif c'est la difficulté qu'on peut éprouver parfois quand on doit choisir entre deux équipements. Les stats sont légions et à moins de savoir exactement ce qu'on cherche, ça peut rapidement devenir infernal.

- Le dernier point qui me semble important, c'est la frustration que ce jeu peut apporter. C'est très possible voire très probable que vous ayez enfin réussi à dépasser le niveau 20, le monde semble à votre portée et pourtant vous vous faites bloquer au milieu d'un level par un élite exceptionnellement fort accompagné du boss du niveau qui vous achèvent en 5 coups malgré toutes vos précautions. C'est extrêmement rageant et c'est certainement la raison pour laquelle je n'ai que 70 heures.


Résumé : 

+ grande diversité des classes
+ chaque action compte ...
+ ... et pour les autres il y a des raccourcis
+ les choses à débloquer
+ le lore
+ majoritairement gratuit (pas f2p ou p2w, hein j'ai bien dit gratuit)

- un peu compliqué à prendre en main au début
- frustrant quand on perd au niveau 15 contre un élite un peu craqué qu'on a pas vu venir...
- totalement injuste (mais c'est aussi pour ça qu'on l'aime ^^)
- les quêtes

+- vraiment difficile
+- les succès ... (sérieusement ? 1638 succès ?)

Conclusion

Essayez-le, ça ne coûte rien.

32260069.review:
Overall this is a very good game with a lot of depth and some very fun well designed classes that said its not without its problems,

Partially I take issue with the perma death mechanic. I tend to like games with permadeath as far as rougelike games go. Nethack is amazing a gritty survival game and every playthrough is unique and you feel fragile and human through out it. ToMEs playthroughs all start roughly the same and get better 10/15 levels in. Those first 10 levels are a slog after you have done it a couple of time. Pouring 10 hours into a character then getting a clumsy death when you are on you last life is pretty painful because you have to restart with the same plot, with the same dungeons, and often with the same unique item drops. It becomes uninviting. 

Exploration mode you say then.. but that has no penalty taking away the tension completely. You need a middle mode between exploration and adventure, perhaps losing all your items (bar the three stocked in your box) for a continue? Or at least gaining a life after a major boss. If you pour 10,15,20 hours before dying its a huge time investment and its very punishing. Particularity because the early game is relatively dull. More choice and divergent paths in the early game might help. 

After a death you pretty much have to play with a different class (which are all brilliantly designed and play fluidly with so many build styles changing gameplay/strategy considerably) and it can take awhile to get to grips with how that class functions often this can result in silly deaths. Which is the bizarre thing that you have to play a class to have a good idea of how you want to build it, but due to the time commitment you would rather restart with a different class then master one.

Basically if you have a lot of time to try the different classes and get good go for it! The amount of depth in the character builds is staggering with some really awesome stuff. (I love the time manipulation ones which you can really mess around with placements and divide and pool enemies together) but all of them offer valid play styles, from adaptable to min-maxing synergies. The depth of build is the real core strength of this game and trying a new class is what makes you play again after a bad beat. There are very little games with this much content and its a lot of value for money. 

Pros:

Intelligent strategic gameplay

Huge choice of classes and viable builds within classes offering dozens of different play-styles

Challenging game play and while your character improves to godly levels it remains challanging

Enormous amount of content and most of it at a surprisingly high quality

Interesting and engaging mechanics which meaningfully change the game with different classes.

Cons:

Same starting areas get samey 

Punishing consecutive mistakes. 5 bad minutes can destroy a 15 hour playthrough

Weak overwritten lore has potential but is wordy and unengaging with hard to believe motivations between groups

Some bugs that need ironing out

Some mechanics are poorly explained and pretty unclear.

Not really a game that is forgiving to people with a job/relationship/other interests huge time sink with very little value outside of its mechanics 


Would I recommend? Absolutely. Very few games this good at this price range play a few times get some decent playthroughs going then put it down and maybe pick it up again later.

31916241.review:
A quick disclaimer: when checking reviews of a game on Steam, the most important thing I look for is not whether a reviewer gave it a  thumb up or down, but the number of hours he has spent actually playing the game. Never trust a positive review from a guy saying "this is the best game ever" but has only 5h playing it. So many games look great at first, only to be forgotten in a week or two.

Now, take a look at some of the reviews for this game. There are people with over a 1,000 hours of ToME behind them. This says a lot about the game's depth, replayability and just sheer fun factor.

I've been a fan of roguelikes for a long time now (maybe for over 15 years? who knows?), and this is hands down the best one I've ever played. The designer knew what to focus on instead of flooding the game with half-implemented features that end up taking away from the fun of the game. There is no hunger, consumables etc. Heck, even crafting was only added in a recent DLC, and even then it's only a small detail.

So what is there that it has? The best and most creative class-system ever seen in an RPG game, together with a great tactical combat system, with enemies potentially having access to the same skills as the player. I mean, in this game you can be a chronomancer and one of your skills called "See the threads" allow you to play the same X turns three times and then choose the best thread to make it "reality". Another class literally possesses mobs and uses their own powers. Every class is very unique and plays very differently. The unique items that can drop are also very cleverly designed, giving you unique and fun powers and not just being a pumped-up version of a normal item with the name in a different color.

Other than that, the game is very hard, which can be frustrating for some, but there are many permadeath options for the less hardcore players out there. The lore is also very rich, even though lore is not really something I care about in these games.

The only downside I can think of are the graphics, which are just bad. No one expects AAA graphics from a roguelike, but ToME just looks kitsch.

31709280.review:
I think I finally have played enough to do a light review.

ToME was a game when I first saw it on Steam I said not interested, it looked clunky, uninteresting, boring, etc. I had no want or need to play it and then quickly forgot about it being a thing. It wasn't until just two weeks ago I saw the video SplatterCat did on ToME that I began to look into it, and with a little amount of worry I bought into ToME. All I can say is this game and the community/developers behind it are some of the best in RPG gaming I have seen in awhile. Playing games as a High Elf Archmage, A Woodelf Druid, a Human Bulwark, A Dwarven Bulwark, A Ghoul Doomfinger, and so much more brought me huge enojyment and I have since then slaved away at being just the base game (about 10 runs in now). I look forward to beating the base campaign and trying out the Orcs campaign DLC and testing out new race and class options, the one thing this game is not short on is choices. I could see myself playing this game for 200+ hours and beyond thanks to the expansive options avaliable to me, if you love DF adventure mod, Path of Exile, or Divinity Original Sin you will enjoy this game.

PLEASE NOTE:
I use mods to play this game, specifically 2 class packs and a mod that lets me have a party instead of the 1 character (role playing my friends into the game) I do not pretend to be an expert or any good at any RPG, the only thing I am interested in is fun and these mods amplify that fun a lot for me.

FINAL VERDICT:
9/10
I really wish the party gameplay was base game, that is literally my only complaint.

31402700.review:
This is my first "roguelike" although I have played a lot of RPGs before. Basically what that means is it's turn-based, levels are procedurally generated, it's fairly challenging, and there is permadeath. (The last can be tweaked a bit in different modes but there are no save slots in any mode.)

The graphics are obviously not the Witcher 3, but are good enough, in a nice semi-realistic "classic fantasy" style. (I personlly don't like cartoony graphics like say Torchlight.)

The music is surprisingly good, some of it is available here if you're curious- https://www.jamendo.com/artist/2740/celestial-aeon-project?language=en

The gameplay is very deep. There are dozens of different classes, including rather exotic ones like "Oozemancer" and one that dual wields shields. Some of these are initially locked (one of the few questionable design decisions IMO), but that can be changed with a mod. There are the usual stats like INT and STR, plus a lot of different resistances and abilities. One nice thing is that bosses are generally not immune to things like stun and slow. Some games (Final Fantasy for example) have trash mobs that are too easy to bother using debuffs on, but then the bosses are immune, so a lot of the spells are pointless. Here you find yourself using all of your abilities fairly frequently.

One of the areas it really shines is in eliminating anything that is tedious. For example, most RPGs have consumables, and you can cheese things by stocking up on them, which requires grinding. Instead of consumables you have "infusions" that are basically swappable skills with cooldowns. This means you have to time your cooldowns well, and be humble enough to run away sometimes, instead of just buying a stack of potions. Another is you can automatically explore a zone. This doesn't make the game easier exactly, since these type of things aren't challenging, just boring. It is really good at streamlining things without dumbing them down.

Given that it's procedurally generated, the story is I would say above average but not amazing, although the writing is quite good and there is a lot of lore. Instead it focuses on replayability and different game modes. There are about 1,300 achievements, however many of these are duplicates based on the three different permadeath modes (permadeath one life, permadeath multiple lives and no permadeath) and difficulty levels. I think there are 9 combinations so 1,300 / 9 = ~140 achievements roughly. Still a decent number. And with so many classes you can definitely have a lot of different playthroughs.

For the price I wasn't expecting much, but was very pleasantly surprised. This is not one of those trendy, shallow gimmicky indie games that you play for a few hours then get bored. It's deep, engaging and very well designed and thought out.

剣と魔法の世界を背景にした、ターン制の伝統的なローグライクゲームです。

Normal で数プレイした程度の感想ですが、以下のように良いと感じる点が多く、全体的な完成度も高いと感じました。

・キャラクタービルドパターンが豊富
・１プレイのコンテンツ量は充分（良し悪しだと思う人も居るでしょうが）

・拾える装備品も良品の出る頻度がいい具合に調整されていて、毎冒険で戦果が楽しみ
・各パラメータ・スキル・状態変化などは、全てに説明が書いてあり、それを読めば（大方は）効果が理解できる
・時々拾える、世界観を説明するようなショートストーリーが面白い

31364435.review:
So much replayability its insane.
Tons of classes and races to choose from each with their own unique abilities and playstyles. No two classes feel the same. You have your basic classes like Archer, Archmage, Rogue and Berserker and then there's also really weird classes like the Possesor, the Temporal Warden (control time and space) and a class that uses the power of dreams and thoughts. (and many more, I think there's like a total of 30 classes)
In one playthrough you won't be able to see everything a class has to offer, so that gives you reason to even try out a class you already played as again but as a different race.

There's a basic campaign mode, an arena mode where you just fight enemies and an endless dungeon mode.

You can choose whether you want to play it as a rogue-like, have a limited number of lives or have infinite lives.

Something I really like is this game lacks consumables, you just gain healing or mana regaining abilities that have a cool down.

Then there's dozens of different mods that add even more content to the game. There is so much freedom in this game its ridiculous.

30987410.review:
I've played over 450 hours of ToME thus far.  I'm not a great player - I tend to get overconfident and get in way over my head.  But ToME is fun.

So what makes Tales of Maj'Eyal special?  Why do I keep going back to it year after year, giving it more of my time than almost every other game in my not insubstantial collection?  

There's a grand diversity in the characters you can play, and their play styles are very different.  You have multiple campaigns, as well as the recently improved Infinite Dungeon.  

The skill selection is great.  Lots of skills to choose from, each with multiple levels.  Races usually have their own skill progression tree, as well.  There are passive skills, sustained skills (that opponents can turn off sometimes), and active skills.  Each of the active skills has a cooldown.  Some items will give you access to active skills as well, or reduce a cooldown on a skill, or make a whole skill tree a little more effective.  

Any active skill can be auto-triggered, if you like.  Most of the races have an instant skill to start off with that gives them some benefit, and you can just say "Yeah, when someone closes in on me, fire off that skill" and you don't have to worry about it anymore.  

Which brings us to auto-explore.  Like DCSS, ToME has a great auto-explore, so when you're not min-maxing your character or finding awesome artifacts, you're making meaningful decisions.  

In the end, those meaningful decisions almost always end in your demise.  As someone once said: "Playing a roguelike is like being a kamikazi pilot: you start off knowing you're going to die."  Rare is the explorer who does not meet some untimely end.  And that too is part of the charm of roguelikes: it's so very often quickly over, but every so often you luck out and live longer than you have any right to.  And you feel like such a bad-ass.  And then you die.  Again.

30936421.review:
This is mostly an old-fashioned turn-based roguelike (by opposition to rogue-lites like Spelunky and Binding of Isaac, which are usually real-time), though it lacks the item identification and the potion and scroll consumables we've come to love from its ancestor Angband, or better titles like NetHack and Dungeon Crawl Stone Soup. It also really likes cooldown-based abilities, so at times you'll feel like you're doing MMO combat.

I found the game too easy initially on Normal, starting the game as a Cornac Berserker regular enemies were no challenge at all, only bosses took some work to kill. The game also drops you in a forest which is quite boring to explore, and the graphics don't make very clear which tiles are traversable and which are not. I recommend using the auto-explore function ('Z' key, rebindable) in levels where you're mostly meeting trash mobs.

With time the game ups the challenge (and you can run into very dangerous areas if you're not careful, the game gives you a message which alludes to the difficulty when changing zones), and with level-ups you start discovering the deep RPG and item system. No complaints here, developing and equipping your character is very interesting, even though the game drowns you a in a sea of magic items with prefixes and suffixes, like Diablo and its ilk. (And unlike diablo, it has a lot of very small modifications to 10+ damage types. Yawning when you find yet another super-rare/legendary is never a good sign.) You unlock new characters and features through quests in the game, which I found cool.

Combat is quite compelling whenever there's a sense of danger. As in most roguelikes, not getting surrounded and paying attention to everything before making a move is key. Between equipment, infusions/runes and skills, you have a lot of abilities with cooldowns, so most turns will be spent picking the right one or positioning yourself to use one rather than simply running into an enemy to auto-attack. What I was most impressed with is when facing boss-type characters, they use pretty much the same ability system as you, and they sometimes have a lot of skills. While it makes identifying a dangerous enemy at a glance pretty hard, it does make for rather epic fights as they cast spells, heal and trigger cooldown abilities just like you. Trust me, the first time you meet an enemy with knockback and spells is really scary when playing a melee character.

The interface, however, is [b]REALLY AWFUL[/b] (despite ridiculous frontpage claims of "modern graphical and customisable interface, intuitive mouse control"), especially the inventory. It's not really comfortable to use with the mouse: instead of displaying a tooltip for what you're hovering your cursor over, it insists on always having some object selected, obscuring your view with the information display. Movement with the mouse is also not very intuitive, as your character will move to where you point... until it finds something "interesting" or an enemy, and then you have to revert to moving a square at a time if you want any semblance of control.[b] It would actually seem like a good idea to learn the game solely with the keyboard at first, maybe even play another, keyboard only roguelike before this one. Only then will the mouse control layer make full sense.[/b] There's also a problem of information overload when looking at map tiles (and other stuff): do I really need to know that I need a "special breathing method" to traverse walls everytime I'm looking at one? The game cruelly needs to display only crucial information at a glance, and then offer to say, press shift to show detailed info like now in the tooltip (see Civilization IV and V and its most complex mods for good examples).

The game has a fixed overworld, story elements and quite a bit of lore, which set it apart from NetHack and Crawl which only offer a giant dungeon. I found this refreshing, but I it comes with suggested level indications for dungeons and minimum levels to use some items, very jarring and immersion-breaking compared to the natural increase in difficulty as you go down in levels in other titles. It's gonna have a massive impact on replayability, too, the world map feels pretty small. There are towns and shops to return to and sell your loot: I think I slightly prefer the approach of Crawl where you can't sell stuff or transfer it to other characters, so you just dump stuff you don't need without hesitation. But if you like sorting through tons of loot Diablo or Borderlands-style, you'll be happy with this game.

There's no downside to resting ('R' key) in this game. In fact I recommend resting as soon as you finish beating a group of enemies, to recharge your health and stamina and bring all your abilities off cooldown. (Annoyingly, some charge bars like "equilibrium" which is need for some powers are ignore by the rest function, leading you to spam the skip turn button or use a mod if you want to get back into an optimal state.) Having to spam rest like this doesn't feel too great, it feels like the game had a hunger mechanic like other roguelikes to urge you on and prevent abusing rest, but dropped it along the way leaving Rest feeling orphaned.

There are a few other weird leftovers in the game, like a "Scrying Orb" which auto-identifies objects... and is completely pointless since objects always auto-identify in this game. Somehow the author hacked that in with a magical item at some point and left it as-is. Also, most annoyingly the game drowns you in loot but unlike, say, Crawl, anything you leave on the floor will disappear after a while. EXCEPT in "vaults", small enclosed areas with treasure guarded by monsters. Good luck identifying what was a vault when coming back to an area you've cleared, though, there are no indications except the room shape. This is an annoying non-feature you'll feel compelled to use, if only to stash stuff until you find the player home (which is also the in-game location of your te4.org, microtransaction-fueled online item Vault), or to make sets of element-resistant armor for various situations.

Overall I quite like the game, but it has a lot of room for improvements in the UI and graphics clarity department. Some of the gameplay choices made that set it apart from other roguelikes give a different, but not necessarily better experience. And as mentioned there are small but nasty oversights in the game design, which ends up feeling like a work in progress based on other roguelikes rather than its own thought-out entity. The community also seems to be blind to most of these flaws, and over-protective of any choice the author makes.

Try it out to experience the sheer amount of content a true roguelike can offer, but do expect a flawed gem. It might be the best game in the Angband family of roguelikes, having gotten rid of annoying stuff like non-persistent levels while still offering mechanics pretty unique to the family like multiplying creatures.

[i]You can go to my Steam profile for more info on classical Roguelikes and suggestion of both free and paid ones.[/i]

I love this game.  Until yet another of my lovingly, painstakingly crafted characters die.  Which happens a lot.  And then I hate it with a passion.  My blood boils.  I bark profanities.  I rage at the unfairness of it all.  I slam my fists down and swear that I'll never play this crappy cheating killfest of a game ever again.  And I sulk.  I pout.  Maybe I pound down a half gallon of ice cream.  I curl up in a fetal ball and weep a bit, wondering if I'll ever find a game that doesn't treat me so badly.

Then I play some other rouguelike for a while.  But it's not the same.  I think wistfully of the good times.  The robust character creation.  The dynamic levelling.  The intriguing quests.  I suppose it wasn't all the game's fault.  I played my part, after all.  But I can't go back.  It will only hurt me again.  Or will it?

So I crawl back on my hands and knees like the sucker I am and beg to be taken back.  Why?  Because I love this game.  And you will, too.  Until you die.   Which will happen a lot.

30806108.review:
This is a roguelike done right.  And a free-to-play done right as well.

The world in which the game takes place is deep and immersive, with a rich history you'll rarely see in any game, roguelike or otherwise.  Character creation is incredibly complex... but in a good way.  Same with the implementation of the different classes' talents / skills.  The game somehow manages all this depth and complexity while still being approachable to the less hardcore roguelike fans.  The interface is fairly intuitive, and there's a solid tutorial to help players new to the genre to get a general idea how to play.

There are difficulty levels, which is already pretty unusual for a roguelike, but even better than that, three different game modes.  The masochists (myself included) can have permadeath while casual players can get into the game with Exploration mode, letting them die any number of times without any harsh penalties.  There's even an Adventure setting which gives players up to 7 lives (gained when reaching certain levels) allowing in-between players a chance to experience the intense thrill that only a permadeath-style game can offer, without over-punishing a small mistake.

The game is even more amazing in that it is 100% free.  You can download it for free.  You can even play with the source code if you are so inclined.  The game engine powering ToME is a separate package you can use to build your own games.  And yet it isn't supported by in-game ads (unless you count the very minimal starting-screen ads strictly for ToME DLC) or pay-to-win mechanics.  The entire game's revenue is based on players either buying DLC (which is absolutely not required to thoroughly enjoy the game) and donations (which is effectively what you're doing if you buy on steam).  Donators get access to some special content, and it's good stuff to be sure, but it's not required to have a ton of fun.

I feel like I need to buy this an extra time or two just to support the amazing product and the one (ones?) responsible for it.

I can't go into depth about game specifics; that would take me weeks to write.  Just trust me: it's an exceptional game with some really amazing features, and you can try it yourself for free if you aren't convinced.

(The free version is probably not on Steam, so go to the game's website if you're too broke to pony up the $7 for it)

30742892.review:
Oh wow, where to begin?

This game is great. What it lacks in visuals is more than made up for in content. It's one of those games that you'll die a lot in, but each time you'll learn something new and think "Alright, one more playthrough, I've got this figured out now". Later, you realize that you've been playing for the past 12 hours, your eyes hurt, and you still have a lot more learning to do. 

ToME can be kind of intimidating at first glance. There's a million different spells, skills, and traits that you can pick through, and it's up to you to learn which ones to use and when. I suggest starting simple, find a skill or two to use that kills stuff, and slowly try to branch out from there so you don't get overwhelmed and quit. If you give this game a chance, you'll more than likely fall in love with it.

There's a variety of different classes, many of which require you to complete a certain quest or objective with a starter class before they are unlocked. The game's difficulty scales fairly well, you're (probably) not going to die immediately upon starting a new campaign, and the first few quest chains aren't too difficult, which provides new players with some time to learn the basic mechanics of the game. In order to truly succeed in the game, however, significant attention will need to be put into resistances and learning which enemies do what kind of damage. Preparation and strategy are required, sprinting into battles is a good way to die, trust me, I know.

The game is difficult, so be prepared. I have nearly 100 hours into the game and - sadly - still have not beaten the campaign. Despite this, I highly recommend the game. It's rewarding, fun, and has high replayability (look at the hours played of 95% of the reviewers). Do yourself a favor and buy ToME.

One last thing, this game goes on sale a LOT. Typically for 50-75% off. If you still run a paper route and $6.99 is too steep for your blood, wait for one of these sales and say "Goodbye" to your free time.

30733865.review:
I have been playing ToME for a while now, and I am still enjoying it.
The game is turn based roguelike about creating a character from a race/class combination, and slowly growing stronger by killing monsters and finding random items while trying to not die.
The world, the general theme of the dungeons and the main quests are always the same, but each dungeon floor is unique for the playthrough.
The game is not always fair, but at some level I really enjoy randomly ending up in bad situations, like what to do when you're all of a sudden being cut off from the stairs to the previous level, poisoned, low on hp, and surrounded by monsters; with practise and a bit of thought and soime luck a lot of bad situations are possible to come out of alive, and I find it hugely rewarding when I manage to pull off an unlikely escape to come back and clean up after recovering.

The game contains a large number of secrets that allow more character creation options when they are discovered, which I feel adds a lot of depth to the game; I'm still trying to find them all.

Leveling up allows some skill points to be allocated to any group of skills you know (Some groups may be added to the basic set of skilkls from your race / class combination), and stat points to be distributed among a fairly standardized set of stats. I feel that it is a bit unfortunate that the skills typically scale off a particular stat, for example berserkers have skills that scale off of strength and vitality, so investing in other stats is hard to justify.

The game is still under active development, and patches to address balance issues or add content or fix bugs are released regularly.
This can be a bit of a mixed blessing, as sometimes monsters that used to be easy yesterday all of a sudden can get you killed because they were buffed in a patch.

The game seems to have some minor annoying bugs that still haven't been fixexd, and a few major ones seem to bite people occationally. As of the latest patch the game seems to have trouble saving when playing online at times, but I am sure this will be fixed soon. As I understand it the entire game was created by a single developer, and given how many things there are that interact I think that he has done a very good job.

The graphics could be prettier, and the engine could probably be optimized a lot, but if you can stand dying a lot in the beginning while learning how everything works the game is really fun and rewarding with a high skill ceiling for players who enjoy exploring and creating powerful characters who survive against all odds, and if you haven't picked up this (slightly unpolished) gem already I strongly suggest you do.

30664699.review:
Pros- 
+The game is one of the most enoyable actual "Rogue likes" I've played.
+Good range of class and race combinations allowing for a relatively deep customisation (uses still sprites but the sprites aren't lacking, they are both serious for the role player and humerous for the more light hearted run throughs)
+Good sense of humour from both the game and the developer. (Ie / only a few nights ago the dev set out a bunch of random events including but not limited to handing out gold to turning you into a bunny with 20% crit chance.)
+Lore is pretty damn Interesting
+Its literally pennies for how much gameplay you can actually get.
+Achievements! Achievements 1000+ Achievements for all you achievement junkies :P
+Classes are and usually split into two obvious builds, sometimes more for the more.. creative players, and require some planning thought, example being a Spell sword, who focuses on casting and uses melee as an alt or who uses sword play and only uses magic to bolster his sword swings / damage.
+Seems to be a lot of very varied items and gear all of which, especially items bearing prefixes and affixes can be incredibly useful and generally all can compliment some type fo character build

Cons - Theres actually very few cons other than the few below, BUT the game is Niche, this won't fulfil every RPG "roguelike" fan.
-Graphics are litlle basic (May or may not put people off, personally doesn't bother me as the game is far too good to sit and complain about how it looks too)
-Have experienced a few lock ups on tabbing out during load screens (probably a dumb thing to do but Youtube ads don't skip themselves...)
-Utterly Unreal amount of achievements may actually cause people to slog through the game not enjoying it.
-RNG can really screw you over.
-Game is incedibly difficult (for those who would rather face roll than think and believe they are the ultimate warrior/gamer)
-Enemies can be very, very unfair if you get unlucky, which can be disheartening in rogue like perma death difficulty as there can be situations where your character may as well just drop his weapon and bend over.

发个临时解决办法，订阅这个汉化MOD之后，游戏目录TalesMajEyal\game\addons\下有个tome-chn123.teaa的文件，最好先备份一份此文件，然后用解压缩工具打开此文件，删除压缩包内的一下文件：
tome-chn123.teaa/superload/data/talents/techniques/archery.lua
tome-chn123.teaa/superload/data/talents/techniques/dualweapon.lua
tome-chn123.teaa/superload/data/talents/techniques/excellence.lua
tome-chn123.teaa/superload/data/talents/techniques/field-control.lua
tome-chn123.teaa/superload/data/talents/cunning/poisons.lua
tome-chn123.teaa/superload/data/talents/cunning/scoundrel.lua
tome-chn123.teaa/superload/data/talents/misc/npcs.lua
之后就能进游戏了，当然还是有些技能查看时会报错，而且因为删除了这么些文件，部分技能翻译会是英文，另外就是这是1.49的汉化，所以可能部分小改动的技能的汉化描述还是改动前的。着急玩的可以试试这个办法，然后坐等大神们早日汉化出新版的。
P.S. 打了汉化MOD进游戏时主菜单也是英文的，要new game进去之后才会有中文。另外主菜单的Addons菜单里左下角的auto-update on start的勾选不要选中，不然会自动更新MOD。可能造成改动无效，等这个MOD更新之后再打开更新即可。
另P.S. 用此方法玩的时候最好别玩大改的盗贼和弓手，因为技能报错和汉化缺失的问题最严重

30560115.review:
Two problems with this game. One, there's a bug that keeps causing my game to crash randomly and fixing it isn't easy. It's frustrating and tedious and the community isn't all that helpful in fixing it. Two, the gameplay is a bit slow and clunky and the graphics can be a little off-putting. 

Despite those things, the gameplay seems pretty damn unique, fun, well fleshed out, and it feels like there's a LOT of variety. If you have a ton of patience to read complicated stats and paragraphs of text and are willing to play a little bit slowly through a game to get good at it, then this game's for you. It's definitely not for the casual / faint of heart RPG'er, but you can definitely see where it would become massively rewarding and skill-based once you get good at the game. The content seems absolutely massive and I look forward to diving back in once I can figure out the bug ordeal.

30539056.review:
Tales of Maj'Eyal is a must play for anyone who has any kind of interest in the roguelike genre. It's a proper turn-based, grid-based tactical game with perma-death (although you can play it without it if you're a puss :D). 

Set in the fantasy world of Eyal, a land which is filled with deep lore and interesting stories and characters. The number of races and classes available is huge and the varying combinations of these make the game immensely replayable.. And you'll want to replay it because it's incredibly addictive but also very difficult. (you will die. A lot) The difficulty (something which should be expected from any true roguelike) is not unfair however, and there is always a way in which you could have gotten out of the situation which killed you, you just might not know it untill a few playthroughs later. The more you play TOME, the more options for skills and gear and combinations of these you become aware of and this, in turn will increase your chances of surviving a little bit longer.

The game has a huge number of things to unlock by carrying out various actions in the game world, from new races and classes, birth options which affect every character you make thereafter and new skill trees for existing classes. Again, if you have ANY kind of interest in roguelikes (not for everyone for sure) then you owe it to yourself to pick up TOME and spend a few hours learning the basics. If you're anything like me then you will find it hugely satisfying and enjoyable.

The game is actually available for free on the website with an option to donate. Donators and people who buy the steam version will get a few extra bits and pieces plus an extra 'donator class', the possesor. 

Made by one man over a long time, TOME is a labour of love and the creator has no plans to stop anytime soon. The game has recently recieved a free update and more are planned, as well as new future DLC at some point down the line. 

If your not sure, pick up the free version on the site, I can almost guarentee you'll want to donate or buy it on steam after a few hours playing, it's that good you'll want to give something back and support future dev. 

Oh and if you like achievements, this game has more than any other game on steam, over 1600 at time of writing :O
